meta.title: GMAT Study PWA
meta.description: Offline‑first study guide with cheatsheet, patterns, flashcards, quiz mode and notes.

items.title: k‑digit / powers
items.body: Rewrite into 2s and 5s, pair to make 10s, then count digits from the 10‑power.

items.title: Range (smallest possible overall)
items.body: Make ranges overlap as much as possible: the smallest combined range can equal the largest individual range.
items.example: If one group’s range is 20 and the other’s is 25, you can nest the smaller within the larger ⇒ overall range = 25.

items.title: Linear word problems
items.body: Use baseline ± (rate × deviation). Words like ‘over 40’ mean (S−40), not S.

items.title: Constant‑rate burn/drain
items.body: Remaining fraction = 1 − elapsed/total. If both start equal height, H cancels — it’s pure fractions.

items.title: Cost per unit
items.body: Set simple numbers, compute cost/benefit per unit, then convert to ‘percent less.’ Avoid algebra unless forced.
items.example: If A costs 1.5× but lasts 2.5×, then cost/km scales by 1.5/2.5 = 0.6 ⇒ 40% less.

items.title: Scientific notation + percents
items.example: Total = part / fraction. If 77 is 3×10⁻⁶ of total ⇒ total = 77/(3×10⁻⁶) = (77×10⁶)/3.

items.title: Radicals & rationalising
items.body: Multiply by the conjugate to remove radicals in denominators. Expand squares to simplify first.

items.q: If you see powers of 4 with powers of 5, what’s the move?
items.a: Rewrite 4^n → 2^(2n). Pair 2^k·5^k = 10^k. Then count digits from the 10‑exponent.

items.q: Smallest possible overall range when combining two groups?
items.a: Maximise overlap; the smallest combined range can equal the largest individual range.

items.q: What does ‘per 10 mph over 40’ mean algebraically?
items.a: Use the deviation (S−40). Then apply the rate: 0.5 per 10 ⇒ (S−40)/20.

items.q: How do you remove radicals from a denominator like (√a−√b)?
items.a: Multiply by the conjugate (√a+√b). Expand squares first if that simplifies.

items.q: If y increases 10% and you have y² in the denominator, what happens?
items.a: The denominator multiplies by (1.1)² = 1.21, so the whole expression is divided by 1.21.

sections.subtitle: Critical reasoning, sentence correction and reading comprehension

notes.title: Evaluating a^b b^c with a>0, b=2a, c=4a
steps: Identify that b equals 2a and c equals 4a by substituting b=2a and c=2b.
Rewrite a^b as a^(2a) and b^c as (2a)^(4a).
Expand (2a)^(4a) into 2^(4a) × a^(4a).
Combine exponents: a^(2a) × a^(4a) = a^(6a). Multiply by 2^(4a) to get 16^a × a^(6a).
Express 16^a × a^(6a) as (16 a^6)^a.

notes.title: Minimising number of bonuses
steps: Recognise that each bonus amount ($750, $1,500, and $7,350) must be used at least once.
To minimise the number of employees, maximise the number of $7,350 bonuses because larger bonuses reduce the count.
Divide the total $64,800 by $7,350. The largest integer less than this quotient is 8, giving 8 × $7,350 = $58,800.
Subtract $58,800 from $64,800 to find $6,000 remaining. Use $1,500 and $750 bonuses to make $6,000 (three $1,500 and two $750 bonuses).
Add the counts: 8 large bonuses + 3 middle bonuses + 2 small bonuses = 13 total bonuses.

notes.title: Simplifying (√8! + √9!)²
steps: Write the sum as √8! + 3√8!, then square it using (a + b)² = a² + b² + 2ab.
Compute the cross term: 2·√8!·3√8! = 6·8!.
Add these together to get 16·8!. Recognise that 16 = 2^4 and 8! contains 2^7 factors of 2, so the highest power of 2 dividing the result is 2^(4+7) = 2^11.

notes.title: Divisibility of k^4 by 32
steps: Rewrite 32 as 2^5. For k^4 to be divisible by 2^5, k must have enough factors of 2.
If k contains 2^t, then k^4 contains 2^(4t). You need 4t ≥ 5, so t ≥ 2.
Therefore k must be divisible by 2^2 = 4.
Any integer divisible by 4 leaves a remainder divisible by 4 when divided by 32. Among the given choices, only 4 works.

notes.title: Simplifying (√15−4√14 + √15+4√14)²
steps: Recognise the structure (√A + √B)², which expands to A + B + 2√(AB). Here A = 15 − 4√14 and B = 15 + 4√14.
Multiply A and B as a difference of squares: (15 − 4√14)(15 + 4√14) = 15² − (4√14)² = 225 − 16·14 = 1.
Take the square root of AB: √1 = 1.
Combine the terms: A + B + 2√(AB) = 30 + 2·1 = 32.

notes.title: Solving (x−y)² + 2y² = 27
steps: Since squares grow quickly, both (x−y)² and 2y² must be small and their sum is 27. Check small integer values of y.
For |y| > 3, 2y² exceeds 27, so possible values of y are −3 to 3.
Test y = −1. The equation becomes (x+1)² + 2 = 27 ⇒ (x+1)² = 25, which has integer solutions x = 4 and x = −6.
Of the answer choices (−2, −1, 3, 4, 5), only x = 4 works with some integer y.
Therefore 4 is a possible value of x.

notes.title: Solving x + √x = 1
steps: Introduce a substitution t = √x, so that x = t². The equation becomes t² + t = 1.
Rearrange to t² + t − 1 = 0 and solve using the quadratic formula.
The solutions to t² + t − 1 = 0 are (−1 ± √5)/2. A square root cannot be negative, so only t = (√5 − 1)/2 is valid.
Therefore √x = (√5 − 1)/2.

quant.p: You see 4^9 × 5^17. What’s the fastest plan?
opts: Rewrite 4^9 as 2^18 and pair 2s with 5s into 10s
quant.why: 4^9 = 2^18. Pair 2^17×5^17 = 10^17 leaving 2×10^17 → count digits.
quant.hint: Try to rewrite 4 as 2×2 and pair factors of 2 with 5.

quant.p: Two month ranges are 20 and 25. Smallest possible combined range?
quant.why: Fully overlap the intervals; the smallest overall range equals the largest individual range (25).
quant.hint: When can you overlap ranges completely?

quant.p: “Penalty of 0.5 mpg per 10 mph over 40.” Speed is S ≥ 40. Penalty term?
quant.why: 0.5 per 10 mph → divide by 20, and “over 40” → use (S−40).
quant.hint: Think of the deviation (S−baseline) divided by the unit interval.

quant.p: Convert 0.0003% into a decimal (or scientific notation).
quant.hint: Be sure to divide the percent by 100.

quant.p: If y increases 10% and you have y^2 in the denominator, overall factor is…
quant.why: The denominator scales by (1.1)^2, so the whole expression is divided by 1.21.
quant.hint: Square the multiplier because the factor is squared.

quant.p: To simplify 1/(√3−√2), the move is…
quant.why: Multiplying by the conjugate removes radicals in the denominator.
quant.hint: Conjugates rationalise denominators containing square roots.

quant.p: Given b = 2a and c = 4a, which is equivalent to a^b b^c?
quant.why: a^b = a^{2a} and b^c = (2a)^{4a} = 2^{4a}·a^{4a}. Combine exponents: 2^{4a}·a^{6a} = (16a^6)^a.
quant.hint: Express everything in terms of a, then combine exponents.

quant.p: A company awards bonuses of $750, $1,500 and $7,350 each. The total amount of the bonuses is $64,800, and each amount is given to at least one employee. To minimise the number of bonuses, how many $7,350 bonuses should be given?
quant.why: 64,800 ÷ 7,350 ≈ 8.8, so you can give 8 bonuses of $7,350 without exceeding the total.
quant.hint: Divide the total by the largest bonus and take the greatest integer less than the result.

quant.p: After awarding eight $7,350 bonuses, how much money remains to be allocated using the other bonuses?
quant.hint: Subtract the amount already allocated from the total.

quant.p: How many $1,500 bonuses and $750 bonuses are needed to allocate the remaining $6,000?
quant.why: To make $6,000 you can use three $1,500 bonuses ($4,500) and two $750 bonuses ($1,500).
quant.hint: Find a combination of 1,500 and 750 that sums to 6,000.

quant.p: How many total bonuses did the company award to sum $64,800 using $750, $1,500, and $7,350 bonuses (each used at least once)?
quant.why: 8 large bonuses, 3 middle bonuses and 2 small bonuses give 13 total bonuses.
quant.hint: Add up the number of each type of bonus.

quant.p: Identify the relationship between b and c if a > 0, b = 2a and c = 2b.
quant.why: Substitute b = 2a into c = 2b to get c = 2·2a = 4a.
quant.hint: Use substitution to express c in terms of a.

quant.p: 9! can be expressed as ___ times 8!.
quant.why: 9! = 9×8! by definition of factorial.

quant.p: √(8! × 9!) equals
quant.hint: Break the square root into the product of square roots.
Factor out √8! and use (a + b)^2 = a^2 + b^2 + 2ab.

quant.p: What is the greatest integer n such that 2^n divides (√8! + √9!)^2?
quant.why: 16 = 2^4 and 8! contains 2^7, so 2^(4+7) = 2^11 divides the result.
quant.hint: Break the result into 16×8! and count factors of 2 in each part.

quant.p: For k^4 to be divisible by 32 (2^5), how many factors of 2 must k contain?
quant.why: If k = 2^t×…, then k^4 has 2^(4t). 4t ≥ 5 ⇒ t ≥ 2, so k must be divisible by 4.
quant.hint: Set 4t ≥ 5 and solve for t.

quant.p: Which remainder r could k leave when divided by 32 if k^4 is divisible by 32?
quant.why: k must be divisible by 4, so r must be a multiple of 4. Of the options, only 4 qualifies.
quant.hint: Look for remainders that are multiples of 4.

quant.why: The radical terms cancel: √15 − 4√14 + √15 + 4√14 = 30.
quant.hint: Group like terms and notice the ±4√14 cancel.
Use the difference‑of‑squares formula.

quant.why: It equals (A+B)^2 where A+B=30 and 2√(AB)=2. So the sum is 30+2=32.

quant.p: For (x − y)^2 + 2y^2 = 27 with integers x and y, what values can y take?
quant.hint: Set 2y^2 ≤ 27 and solve for y.

quant.p: If y = −1 in (x − y)^2 + 2y^2 = 27, which x values satisfy the equation?
quant.hint: Substitute y = −1 and solve the resulting quadratic.

quant.p: Which of the following could be the value of x if (x − y)^2 + 2y^2 = 27?
quant.why: Testing small y values shows that x = 4 with y = −1 yields a solution.
quant.hint: Check each x by trying small values of y in the equation.

quant.p: Let t = √x. If x + √x = 1, what equation does t satisfy?
quant.why: Substitute t=√x ⇒ x=t^2. Then t^2 + t = 1 ⇒ t^2 + t − 1 = 0.
quant.hint: Replace x with t^2 and move all terms to one side.

quant.p: Which solution of t^2 + t − 1 = 0 is valid for t = √x?
quant.why: The quadratic formula gives t = (−1 ± √5)/2. Only (√5 − 1)/2 is non‑negative and equals √x.
quant.hint: A square root must be non‑negative.
